title: You Are Worthy Before Any Accomplishment
summary: An overworked EMS dispatcher doubts her worth—until a friend likens her to a flower that deserves sunlight by existing. Over coffee, she rediscovers her inherent value, aligning with the idea that self-worth is unconditional and shines before any task.
story:
Jessa navigated through the humid evening traffic of Quezon City, her headset crackling as calls pinged in rapid succession. As a dispatcher at the city’s busiest EMS center, she prided herself on meeting every demand without fail. Tonight, though, the weight of “what if I’m not enough” pressed on her chest.

She slipped into Sol’s corner café in Cubao, where her friend Miguel was already sipping a warm brew. Miguel, a project coordinator at a startup in Ortigas, looked up with a reassuring grin.

“Long day?” he asked.

“Overwhelming,” Jessa admitted, unhooking her headset. “When I miss a window or can’t arrange an ambulance fast enough, I feel like I’ve let everyone down. I worry my job hinges entirely on perfection.”

Miguel leaned forward. “I get that. I used to think my worth as a coordinator was measured by every deliverable I hit. But I’ve been reading about this idea—that our value is inherent, not earned.”

Jessa frowned. “Inherent? You mean I’m valuable even when things go sideways?”

“Exactly,” he said, stirring his coffee. “Think of a flower. It doesn’t have to perform to deserve sunlight. Its value—to bees, to gardens—is part of its essence. You’re like that flower, Jessa. Your care, your calm voice on frantic calls, your unwavering presence—they’re all expressions of who you are, not bonuses you earn.”

She listened as cars honked outside and the café’s soft lights glowed. The dispatcher in her wanted proof—statistics, metrics. But a deeper part of her softened.

“Tomorrow,” Miguel continued, “when another emergency call comes, you’ll show up prepared. But remind yourself first: you’re more than the tasks you complete.”

Jessa tucked her hair behind her ear. “I think I needed to hear that. I’ve forgotten that my value isn’t tied to response times or perfect logistics.”

Miguel raised his mug. “To knowing our worth before the work begins.”

Jessa clinked her mug against his. In that simple toast, she felt a shift: her value, like the lanterns dotting Manila’s night sky, glowed within—steady, inherent, and free of conditions.
